--- title: Parts of a Whole subtitle: "Parts of a Whole" author: "Arvind V." date: 25/Nov/2022 date-modified: "2024-08-19" order: 60 abstract: "Slices, Portions, Counts, and Aggregates of Data" image: preview.jpg image-alt: image from rawpixels.com categories: - Pie Charts - Fan Charts - Donut Charts - Grouping - Stacking - Circular Bar Charts - Dot Plots - Mosaic Charts - Parliament Charts - Waffle Charts bibliography: - grateful-refs.bib citation: true --- ## {{< iconify noto-v1 package >}} Setting up the Packages ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} knitr::opts_chunk$set(tidy = "styler") library(tidyverse) library(mosaic) library(ggformula) library(plotrix) # Fan, Pyramid Chart #devtools::install_github("zmeers/ggparliament") library(ggparliament) # Parliament Chart library(ggpol) # Parliament, Arc-Bar and other interesting charts library(data.tree) # Many plots related to heirarchical data # install.packages("waffle", repos = "https://cinc.rud.is") library(waffle) library(tidygraph) # Trees, Dendros, and Circle Packings library(ggraph) # Trees, Dendros, and Circle Packings library(echarts4r) # Interactive Charts library(patchwork) # Arrange your plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ## {{< iconify fxemoji japanesesymbolforbeginner >}} What Graphs will we see today? There are a good few charts available to depict things that constitute other bigger things. We will discuss a few of these: Pie, Fan, and Donuts; Waffle and Parliament charts; Trees, Dendrograms, and Circle Packings. (The last three visuals we will explore along with `network diagrams` in a later module.) ## {{< iconify noto folding-hand-fan >}} Pies and Fans So let us start with "eating humble pie": discussing a Pie chart first. A `pie chart` is a circle divided into sectors that each represent a proportion of the whole. It is often used to show percentage, where the sum of the sectors equals 100%. The problem is that humans are pretty bad at reading angles. This ubiquitous chart is much vilified in the industry and `bar charts` that we have seen earlier, are viewed as better options. On the other hand, pie charts are ubiquitous in business circles, and are very much accepted! Do also read this spirited defense of pie charts here. And we will also see that there is an attractive, and similar-looking alternative, called a `fan chart` which we will explore here. ::: {.panel-tabset .nav-pills style="background: whitesmoke;"} ### Using Base R Base R has a simple `pie` command that does the job. Let's create some toy data first: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} pie_data <- tibble( sales = c(0.12, 0.3, 0.26, 0.16, 0.04, 0.12), # Labels MUST be character entries for `pie` to work labels = c("Blueberry","Cherry","Apple","Boston Cream", "Other","Vanilla Cream") ) pie_data pie( x = pie_data$sales, labels = pie_data$labels, # Character Vector is a MUST # Pie is within a square of 1 X 1 units # Reduce radius if needed to see labels properly radius = 0.95, init.angle = 90, # First slice starts at 12 o'clock position # Change the default colours. Comment this and see what happens. col = grDevices::hcl.colors(palette = "Plasma", n = 6) ) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ::: :::: ### Using ggformula We create a bar chart or a column chart as appropriate, with bars filled by category. The `width` parameter is set to `1` so that the bars touch. The bars have a **fixed** width along the x-axis; the height of the bar varies based on the number we wish to show. Then the `coord_polar(theta = "y")` converts the bar plot into a pie. ::: {.cell layout-nrow="2" layout-ncol="2" layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # Set graph theme theme_set(new = theme_custom()) # Using gf_col since we have a count/value column already pie_data %>% gf_col(sales ~ 1, fill = ~ labels, width = 1) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/ggformula-pie-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} pie_data %>% gf_col(sales ~ 1, fill = ~ labels, width = 1) %>% gf_refine(coord_polar(theta = "y")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/ggformula-pie-2.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Using gf_bar since we don't have ready made counts gf_bar(data = mpg, ~ 1, fill = ~ drv, color = "black", # border for the bars/slices width = 1) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/ggformula-pie-3.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} gf_bar(data = mpg, ~ 0.5, fill = ~ drv, color = "black", # border for the bars/slices width = 1) %>% gf_theme(theme_minimal()) %>% gf_theme(theme(axis.line.y = element_blank(), axis.text.y = element_blank(), axis.title.y = element_blank())) %>% gf_refine(coord_polar(theta = "y")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/ggformula-pie-4.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ### Using echarts4r Here is a basic interactive pie chart with`echarts4r`: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} pie_data <- tibble( sales = c(0.12, 0.3, 0.26, 0.16, 0.04, 0.12), labels = c("Blueberry","Cherry","Apple","Boston Cream","Other", "Vanilla Cream")) pie_data %>% e_charts(x = labels) %>% e_pie(serie = sales, clockwise = TRUE, startAngle = 90) %>% e_legend(list(orient = "vertical", left = "right")) %>% e_tooltip() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: We can add more bells and whistles to the humble-pie chart, and make a Nightingale `rosechart` out of it: ::: {.cell layout-ncol="2" layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} pie_data <- tibble( sales = c(0.12, 0.3, 0.26, 0.16, 0.04, 0.12), labels = c("Blueberry","Cherry","Apple","Boston Cream","Other", "Vanilla Cream")) pie_data %>% e_charts(x = labels) %>% e_pie(serie = sales, clockwise = TRUE, startAngle = 90, roseType = "area") %>% # try "radius" # Lets move the legend e_legend(left = "right", orient = "vertical") %>% e_tooltip() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} pie_data %>% e_charts(x = labels) %>% e_pie(serie = sales, clockwise = TRUE, startAngle = 90, roseType = "radius") %>% # Lets move the legend e_legend(left = "right", orient = "vertical") %>% e_tooltip() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: For more information and customization look at ::: ### The `fan` Plot The `fan plot` (from the `plotrix` package) displays numerical values as arcs of **overlapping sectors**. This allows for more effective comparison: :::: {.columns} :::{.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # Set graph theme theme_set(new = theme_custom()) plotrix::fan.plot( x = pie_data$sales, labels = pie_data$labels, col = grDevices::hcl.colors(palette = "Plasma", n = 6), shrink = 0.03, # How much to shrink each successive sector label.radius = 1.15, main = "Fan Plot of Ice Cream Flavours", # ticks = 360, # if we want tick marks on the circumference max.span = pi ) ``` ::: ::: :::{.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ::: :::: There is no fan plot possible with `echarts4r`, as far as I know. ### The `Donut` Chart The `donut` chart suffers from the same defects as the pie, so should be used with discretion. The `donut` chart is essentially a `gf_rect` from `ggformula`, plotted on a **polar coordinate** set of of axes: ::: {.panel-tabset .nav-pills style="background: whitesmoke;"} #### Using ggformula Let us make some toy data: ::: {.cell layout-ncol="2" layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # Set graph theme theme_set(new = theme_custom()) # Data df <- tibble(group = LETTERS[1:3], value = c(25, 20, 35)) df <- df %>% dplyr::mutate(fraction = value / sum(value), # percentages ymax = cumsum(fraction), # cumulative percentages ymin = lag(ymax, 1, default = 0), # bottom edge of each label = paste0(group, "\n value: ", value), labelPosition = (ymax + ymin) / 2 # labels midway on arcs ) df ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} df %>% # gf_rect() formula: ymin + ymax ~ xmin + xmax # Bars with varying thickness (y) proportional to data # Fixed length x (2 to 4) gf_rect(ymin + ymax ~ 2 + 4, fill = ~ group, colour = "black") %>% gf_label(labelPosition ~ 3.5, label = ~ label, size = 4) %>% # When switching to polar coords: # x maps to radius # y maps to angle theta # so we create a "hole" in the radius, in x gf_refine(coord_polar(theta = "y", direction = 1)) %>% # Up to here will give us a pie chart # Now to create the hole # try to play with the "0" # Recall x = [2,4] gf_refine(xlim(c(-2, 5))) %>% gf_theme(theme = theme_void()) %>% gf_theme(legend.position = "none") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/donut-chart-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: #### Using echarts4r The `donut` chart is simply a variant of the pie chart in `echarts4r`: ::: {.cell layout-ncol="2" layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} df <- tibble(group = LETTERS[1:3], value = c(25, 20, 35)) df <- df %>% dplyr::mutate(fraction = value / sum(value), # percentages ymax = cumsum(fraction), # cumulative percentages ymin = lag(ymax, 1, default = 0), # bottom edge of each label = paste0(group, "\n value: ", value), labelPosition = (ymax + ymin) / 2 # labels midway on arcs ) df ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} df %>% e_charts(x = group, width = 400) %>% e_pie(serie = value, clockwise = TRUE, startAngle = 90, radius = c("50%", "70%") ) %>% e_legend(left = "right", orient = "vertical") %>% e_tooltip() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ::: ## {{< iconify noto waffle >}} Waffle Charts Waffle charts are often called "square pie charts" ! Here we will need to step outside of `ggformula` and get into `ggplot` itself momentarily. (Always remember that `ggformula` is a simplified and intuitive method that runs on **top** of `ggplot`.) We will use the `waffle` package. :::: {.columns} :::{.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # Set graph theme theme_set(new = theme_custom()) # install.packages("waffle", repos = "https://cinc.rud.is") library(waffle) # Data df <- tibble(group = LETTERS[1:3], value = c(25, 20, 35)) df ``` ::: ::: :::{.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ::: :::: :::: {.columns} :::{.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # Waffle plot # Using ggplot, sadly not yet ggformula ggplot(df, aes(fill = group, values = value)) + geom_waffle( n_rows = 8, size = 0.33, colour = "white", na.rm = TRUE ) + scale_fill_manual( name = NULL, values = c("#BA182A", "#FF8288", "#FFDBDD"), labels = c("A", "B", "C") ) + coord_equal() + theme_void() ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ::: :::: ## {{< iconify fa6-solid people-roof >}} Parliament Charts The package `ggpol` offers an interesting visualization in the shape of a array of "seats" in a parliament. (There is also a package called `ggparliament` which in my opinion is a bit cumbersome, having a two-step procedure to convert data into "parliament form" etc. ) :::: {.columns} :::{.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # Set graph theme theme_set(new = theme_custom()) # Same toy dataset # df <- tibble(group = LETTERS[1:3], # value = c(25, 20, 35)) # # Parliament Plot ggplot(df) + ggpol::geom_parliament(aes(seats = value, fill = group), r0 = 2, # inner radius r1 = 4 # Outer radius ) + scale_fill_manual(name = NULL, values = c("#BA182A", "#FF8288", "#FFDBDD"), labels = c("A", "B", "C")) + coord_equal() + theme_void() ``` ::: ::: :::{.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ::: :::: ## Trees, Dendrograms, and Circle Packings There are still more esoteric plots to explore, if you are hell-bent on startling people ! There is an R package called `ggraph`, that can do these charts, and many more: > ggraph is an extension of [`ggplot2`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/) > aimed at supporting relational data structures such as networks, > graphs, and trees. While it builds upon the foundation of `ggplot2` > and its API it comes with its own self-contained set of geoms, facets, > etc., as well as adding the concept of *layouts* to the grammar. We will explore these charts when we examine `network diagrams.` For now, we can quickly see what these diagrams look like. Although the R-code is visible to you, it may not make sense at the moment! ### {{< iconify mdi family-tree >}} Dendrograms From the [R Graph Gallery Website](http://r-graph-gallery.com/index.html) : > Dendrograms can be built from: > > - [Hierarchical > dataset](http://r-graph-gallery.com/dendrogram.html#hiera): think > about a CEO managing team leads managing employees and so on. > > - [Clustering > result](http://r-graph-gallery.com/dendrogram.html#clust): > clustering divides a set of individuals in group according to > their similarity. Its result can be visualized as a tree. :::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # create an edge list data frame giving the hierarchical structure of your individuals d1 <- tibble(from = "origin", to = paste("group", seq(1,5), sep = "")) d2 <- tibble(from = rep(d1$to, each=5), to = paste("subgroup", seq(1,25), sep="_")) edges <- rbind(d1, d2) edges ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ::: :::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # Create a graph object mygraph1 <- tidygraph::as_tbl_graph(edges) mygraph1 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tbl_graph: 31 nodes and 30 edges # # A rooted tree # # Node Data: 31 × 1 (active) name 1 origin 2 group1 3 group2 4 group3 5 group4 6 group5 7 subgroup_1 8 subgroup_2 9 subgroup_3 10 subgroup_4 # ℹ 21 more rows # # Edge Data: 30 × 2 from to 1 1 2 2 1 3 3 1 4 # ℹ 27 more rows ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # Set graph theme theme_set(new = theme_custom()) # Basic tree ggraph(mygraph1, layout = 'dendrogram', circular = TRUE) + geom_edge_diagonal() + geom_node_point(size = 3) + geom_node_label(aes(label = name), size = 3, repel = TRUE) + theme(aspect.ratio = 1) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-24-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ::: :::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # create a data frame data <- tibble( level1="CEO", level2=c( rep("boss1",4), rep("boss2",4)), level3=paste0("mister_", letters[1:8]) ) # transform it to a edge list! edges_level1_2 <- data %>% select(level1, level2) %>% unique %>% rename(from=level1, to=level2) edges_level2_3 <- data %>% select(level2, level3) %>% unique %>% rename(from=level2, to=level3) edge_list <- rbind(edges_level1_2, edges_level2_3) edge_list ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ::: :::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} mygraph2 <- as_tbl_graph(edge_list) mygraph2 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tbl_graph: 11 nodes and 10 edges # # A rooted tree # # Node Data: 11 × 1 (active) name 1 CEO 2 boss1 3 boss2 4 mister_a 5 mister_b 6 mister_c 7 mister_d 8 mister_e 9 mister_f 10 mister_g 11 mister_h # # Edge Data: 10 × 2 from to 1 1 2 2 1 3 3 2 4 # ℹ 7 more rows ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # Set graph theme theme_set(new = theme_custom()) # Now we can plot that ggraph(mygraph2, layout = 'dendrogram', circular = FALSE) + geom_edge_diagonal() + geom_node_point(size = 3) + geom_node_label(aes(label = name), repel = TRUE) + theme_void() ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-30-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ::: :::: ### Circle Packing :::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} graph_flare <- tbl_graph(flare$vertices, flare$edges) graph_flare ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tbl_graph: 252 nodes and 251 edges # # A rooted tree # # Node Data: 252 × 3 (active) name size shortName 1 flare.analytics.cluster.AgglomerativeCluster 3938 AgglomerativeCluster 2 flare.analytics.cluster.CommunityStructure 3812 CommunityStructure 3 flare.analytics.cluster.HierarchicalCluster 6714 HierarchicalCluster 4 flare.analytics.cluster.MergeEdge 743 MergeEdge 5 flare.analytics.graph.BetweennessCentrality 3534 BetweennessCentrality 6 flare.analytics.graph.LinkDistance 5731 LinkDistance 7 flare.analytics.graph.MaxFlowMinCut 7840 MaxFlowMinCut 8 flare.analytics.graph.ShortestPaths 5914 ShortestPaths 9 flare.analytics.graph.SpanningTree 3416 SpanningTree 10 flare.analytics.optimization.AspectRatioBanker 7074 AspectRatioBanker # ℹ 242 more rows # # Edge Data: 251 × 2 from to 1 221 1 2 221 2 3 221 3 # ℹ 248 more rows ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # Set graph theme theme_set(new = theme_custom()) set.seed(1) ggraph(graph_flare, 'circlepack', weight = size) + geom_node_circle(aes(fill = as_factor(depth)), size = 0.25, n = 50) + coord_fixed() + scale_fill_discrete(name = "Depth") + theme_void() ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-34-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ::: :::: ## {{< iconify bi person-up >}} Your Turn 1. Use the `penguins` dataset from the `palmerpenguins` package and plot pies, fans, and donuts as appropriate. 2. Look at the `whigs` and `highschool` datasets in the package `ggraph`. Plot Pies, Fans and if you are feeling confident, Trees, Dendrograms, and Circle Packings as appropriate for these. ## {{< iconify ooui references-ltr >}} References 1. Iaroslava.2020. *A Parliament Diagram in R*, \ 2. Venn Diagrams in R, [Venn diagram in ggplot2 \| R CHARTS (r-charts.com](https://r-charts.com/part-whole/ggvenndiagram/))\ 3.
